SP.L: Not more than half, as I am here alive.
Your senses are perhaps awake; but still
Your reason and your judgment are asleep,
Or you would never prattle thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Come then yourself, and be convinc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: There stop that bawling wench, or she will run us all aground.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Oh, murder!

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.L: I must not, will not hold my peace.
Help, ho! murder! murder!

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Let's kill the strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: What! kill me too?

DIV2.STAGE: [Runs out doors and the Sailor after her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: No, fetch her back. Be cautious.
Confusion take her! She will raise the town.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: Can't we hide?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: I know no place.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: There is none.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: Dear me! What shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: Deny the fact,
And charge it on the sailors.

DIV2.STAGE: The Sailor enters, leading in Betty muffled.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: She hollow'd, murder! once or twice, as if the devil swell'd her voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Did any body hear her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.L: The Lord can tell, much better than I can.
Now, by Saint Patrick, you shall die.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: No, hold; don't injure her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Where then shall I stow her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: No matter where.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: See her well muffled first,
Then shut her in the closet there.

DIV2.STAGE: A Neighbour enters with a light.

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.L: What is the cause of this alarm?
Is any body murder'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: It is a false alarm. No hurt is done.

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.P: It has awak'd the town, at any rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: I'm sorry. 'Twas an accident.
We've a distracted person—There she fit:—
Who just now happen'd to get off her chains,
And run out screaming, through the streets,
Like Bediam. That is all. Pray hasten back,
And stop the horrid cry, before it spread.

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.L: There's something more;
What means that dagger in your hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: What this? Raising it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.P: Hah! Bloody too?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: I've bound him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.P: What? Bound up whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Heav'ns! Who art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.P: There's murder here, I say.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. Worthy, Officers and Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.P: Who's murder'd is this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.L: Defend me, Major Shapely;
Do let me lean upon thine arm. Swoons.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: For God's sake, let me call the Doctor in.

SP.SPEAKER: Neigh.
SP.L: He is a knave,

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.P: Then stop him, Officer, and store them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: You upon your death.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Stand off, I say, stand off from me, or by my life, I'll give you a broad-side that will sink you to the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.P: Fear not his threats.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Resign yourselves, or take the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: O guilt!
I cannot fight; something to my arm. Submits.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: Then yield, you heartless coward, and be hang'd,
I'll fight no more in your defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Nor I, by George, I'll see you drown'd in fire and brimstone first.

DIV2.STAGE: Officer and others sieze Shapely, Captain and Sailor.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: [Let loose.] They've kill'd my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.P: Who have?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Those cursed Sailors.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: Ungrateful dog!
He hir'd us to assist. We did no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Unhappy woman! See, she has at fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.L: Bind all the rascals fast.
My God! Is this in ?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: [Reviving.] O Major Shapely! Where art thou? Faints again.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: My dear, I can't afford thee any aid;
Endeavours are in vain: Our all is loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.P: Where is this victim of their murderous guilt?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: In that room, there.

DIV2.STAGE: Mr. Worthy and others go out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.P: [Reviving.] Murder my husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Don't mind it, dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. J.
SP.L: I must. It haunts my guilty thoughts.
Destruction! Oh! What furies hover round,
In haste to snatch me to the horrid pit,
Which yawns, and frightens back my flattering soul!
Yet nature sinks—Death pulls me down a main—
Oh! Oh! I leap eternal precipice.
Adieu. [dies.]

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Her dying gasp! See, she is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: I'll follow her. Attempts to stab himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: Hold, villain. Are you not disarm'd?
There, wait your proper time.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Not suffer me to die a soldier's death?

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: No, you shall be reserv'd,
To grace a rope, on gallows hill.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: There is no remedy; I must submit.
Disgraceful death, and something worse beyond!
That thought lights up damnation in my breast;
Hell stares me in the face, with all its pains.
Oh, darkness and despair!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Now say, the sailors did the crime.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: I lied.
I am a liar, coward, murderer,
And any thing, the worst you can invent.
I've murder'd you, as well as him.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: No, not so bad, for I am yet alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: But death is planted in your blood.
You drank a poison'd dram, that I had mix'd,
Lest you hereafter should divulge the fact:

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: And I too?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Both alike.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Am I then poison'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: To death, you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Certainly? What, by that glass of bitters?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: That very glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: O murder heap'd on murder's head!
This is the consequence of being brib'd,
To strangle other people in their sleep.
A sense of that at once disarms my tongue,
Which else would curse you, to the lowest hell—
Don't roll those guilty, snakish eyes this way;
You scatter poison with your very looks.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.L: Methinks, I feel it working in my veins,
Like spiders crawling over all my flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Pray, give me leave to crush that viper's head.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: No, let the hangman do his work.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: As quick as possible:
For, like a hateful, poison-sucking toad,
This villain has attracted all the guilt,
Within a hundred miles; and hanging him
Will purge the land.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: Oh, horror, guilt and death!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.L: Rejoice, O honest world! rejoice,
When this adept in villany is dead:
But blush, ye monsters of the lower realms,
To see yourselves out-devil'd by a man.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. Worthy, and Attendants bringing in Mr. Jenson's body.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.L: Here lay him down.
See Mrr Jenson's mangl'd corps.

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: And here behold the wretch, who mangled him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.L: Inhuman act!
Look how his garments are besmear'd with blood,
Still streaming from his wound! Observe his eyes—
Not those bright stars, that lately sparkled there;
But glassy balls, roll'd up in stupid glare.
I'll gently close his lids.—There, sleep, my friend,
Poor bleeding, murder'd friend, repose in death.
Those cheeks, which ely bloom'd with youthful smiles,
Are nothing now, alas! but ghastly clods,
Death sets in triumph on his wither'd face.
That tongue, which ably plead his country's cause,
Is stiff? And all his limbs refuse to move.
How will his friends and country mourn his death,
A private, and no less a public loss!
Just mounting to the stage of public life,
Seiz'd by a murderer's hand, and plung'd in death!

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.P: 'Twas I who murder'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wor.
SP.L: Thou child of darkness!
Why didst thou perpetrate the hellish deed?

SP.SPEAKER: Shap.
SP.L: To satiate my desires.
The love of happiness has been my bane;
For this, through peaceful calms and storms of strife,
I've travel'd round the globe of human life;
At length, my race of villany is run,
My guilt compleated and my journey done.
Farewell, sweet hope! expected bliss, farewell!
Come, dire despair, thou blackest imp of hell,
With all the plagues, that form thy cursed train,
Remorse and envy, jealousy and pain;
Come, from the realms of misery below,
And take me down to everlasting woe.

DIV2.TRAILER: The END of the FIFTH ACT.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: TO generous souls, whose sentiments are right▪
The exercise of candour gives delight▪
But other persons, of a different make,
Rejoice to find and censure a mistake.
As every audience is composed of these,
This evening's play must consequently please:
For here are faults of almost every name,
That candour can forgive, or censure blome.
Ye critics, then, and patrons of the stage.
The just resiners of the present age,
Who fill, adorn and dignify these seats,
Pray, grant this savour, which your friend entreats;
Be good enough our foibles to excuse,
Indulge the boldness of a youthfull muse,
And thus declare to each unbiass'd mind,
That skilful judges are most freely kind.
